ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to understand the world of today, from a different perspective.
Both the Instructors conveyed an excellent survey of Modern World History and how to explore it with the tools of a historian.

There are two particular areas of knowledge that this course helped me in enhancing: the lead of to the First World War and, above all, the interwar period. I thought the course gave the students an important opportunity to improve and practice our writing skills. The course furnished me with some interesting insights into how history can be used as a methods of analysis to better undertake effective decision-making.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course should not be solely focused on Europe. The absence of non-European perspectives on major world events like both World Wars is off-putting to many students.

The course would benefit from a longer extended class time in smaller groups: two hour seminars with class sizes of around 15 students. More student discussion of the material should be encouraged. Simulations should be more structured, with clearer expectations.
The strengths lay in the instructors' ability to make the most difficult material accessible and also have a comprehensive reading list for the class.

The main strength of the course was the simulations, which gave me the opportunity to practice and improve my public speaking and negotiation skills. The main weakness of the course was a lack of detailed feedback on the numerous written assignments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would have preferred to take a regionally focused course of my choosing, or if not allowed to choose this course could be improved by including other perspectives on world events because the "present" was not solely constructed by Western states.
Being a compulsory closed course, this one cannot be recommended to non-Jackson scholars. I would have loved to do so and know of people who would have liked to attend the class as well.
